thread.title: Brees, Saints look to change course
thread.title_full: Brees, Saints look to change course

title: Brees, Saints look to change course
text:
Drew Brees, Saints looking to change course after slow start Brees not happy with Saints' 1-4 start. Post to Facebook Drew Brees, Saints looking to change course after slow start Brees not happy with Saints' 1-4 start. Check out this story on shreveporttimes.com: http://usat.ly/1Lt1BqD Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Drew Brees, Saints looking to change course after slow start James Varney, Special for USA TODAY Sports 5:23 p.m. CDT October 13, 2015 New Orleans Saints quarterback Drew Brees (9) prepares to take a snap over center against the Philadelphia Eagles at Lincoln Financial Field. (Photo: Bill Streicher, USA TODAY Sports) 1 CONNECT 9 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
New Orleans Saints quarterback Drew Brees is always even-keeled and professional, but that doesn’t mean he’s putting a smile on for the team’s ugly 1-4 start. 
“I’m not really happy with the way things have gone thus far,” he said Tuesday as New Orleans prepares to host the 5-0 Atlanta Falcons on Thursday night. “So you could say I’m a little bit angry, disappointed, frustrated, chip on the shoulder. I’m harnessing that into something positive.” 
Two weeks ago, Brees missed his first start due to injury since joining the Saints in 2006. Neither he nor the team is about to admit his sore shoulder might be limiting the star, but the Saints’ record would seem to indicate otherwise. Matt Cassel no quick fix for Cowboys' offensive woes 
Surprisingly, though, the Saints' passing attack remains potent. New Orleans averages 302 passing yards per game, third best in the NFL. Though he has played in one fewer game, Brees’ six touchdowns this season match those thrown by Falcons quarterback Matt Ryan. 
But no matter how much emphasis the Saints emphasize the pass, they must answer for a defense that ranks last in the NFL with 409 yards allowed per game. New Orleans has been sloppy with protection, too. Brees has taken more hits at this point in 2015 than at any similar point in his career, and the Saints’ turnover margin of -5 leaves them tied for 28th in the league. 
Still, Brees insisted no one in New Orleans is pushing the panic button despite going 0-2 in the NFC South and in danger of falling further behind with a loss to Atlanta. Week 6 fantasy football rankings 
“I really haven’t stressed about it that much,” Brees said. “I feel like the plays will come. You just got to keep plugging away, keep dialing them up, and good things will start to happen.” 
New Orleans would appear to have one thing in its favor: since 2006, the Saints have won prime time games at home at an impressive 81% clip. The team’s lone win this season came in just that situation, a Sunday night overtime victory over the Dallas Cowboys in Week 4.
